item.title: Path of Exile 2: Which Huntress Ascendancy Should You Choose
item.description:
The Huntress Class in Path of Exile 2 uses a combination of Spears and Bucklers to devastate their enemies. A Huntress can choose to get close up and personal with her enemies or keep her distance, throwing spears from afar.

The most crucial decision every Huntress has to face during the campaign is which Ascendancy to pick: Amazon or Ritualist? This choice is irreversible, meaning it can be respecced down the road.

Which Huntress Ascendancy Should You Choose in PoE 2

The short answer: Amazon. Of the two available ascension paths for the Huntress Class, Amazon and Ritualist, Amazon is clearly the winner. Not only does it mesh well with the Huntress's overall playstyle, but it has some of the most powerful ascendancy skills in the game. Amazon is about all-out offense, with multiple nodes that lean into the hyper-offensive archetype. Here are some of the most powerful nodes in this path:

Ascendancy Node

Description

Benefit

Critical Strike

Chance to Hit with Attacks can exceed 100%. Gain additional Critical Hit Chance equal to 25% of excess chance to Hit with Attacks.

Allows for builds centered around Critical Hits, like Bleed Huntress.

Penetrate

Attacks using your Weapons have Added Physical Damage equal to 25% of the Accuracy Rating on the Weapon.

Since Accuracy Rating is one of the easiest stats to get on your weapon, Penetrate is easy to build around.

Elemental Infusion

Grants Skill: Infuse Weapon

When you Consume a Power Charge Trigger Infuse Weapon to gain 2 Cold Infusion

When you Consume an Endurance Charge Trigger Infuse Weapon to gain 2 Fire Infusion

When you Consume a Frenzy Charge Trigger Infuse Weapon to gain 2 Lightning Infusion

Frenzy Charge is incredibly easy to generate with Combat Frenzy and Sniper's Mark, and Lightning Infusion works extremely well with Lightning Spear.

In comparison, Ritualist lacks in all of these areas. It doesn't do anything to boost what the Huntress already wants to specialize in and the power spike its nodes provide to off-meta builds is underwhelming. The only argument for choosing Ritualist over Amazon is that the Ritualist gains the ability to equip three Rings instead of the regular two and receives a +25% effect from Amulets and Rings. If you have some absolutely insane Rings sitting in your stash, it might be worth experimenting with Ritualist, but even then, it's not worth it. An extremely expensive Ritualist build is only comparable to a relatively cheap Amazon Huntress build even on a good day. That's why it is not recommended to pick Ritualist over Amazon.

item.title: Hollow Knight: Silksong's Switch 2 Direct Footage Revealed More Than a Release Date
item.description:
Its official: Hollow Knight: Silksong is coming in 2025. The most recent Nintendo Direct gave fans of the indie smash hit a brief, four-second taste of the highly anticipated sequel, as well as a release window for sometime later this year. That four-second clip provided a lot of information, including a sample of a new environmental quirk that players never saw before in the first Hollow Knight. It implies that Hollow Knight: Silksong is headed in directions that the first game never dared to go.

Fans of Hollow Knight will have noticed that Hornet is far more agile and acrobatic than her predecessor, the Knight, and the level design shown for the sequel speaks to this. In previous trailers of Hollow Knight: Silksong , Hornet has been shown utilizing her environment in brand new ways. She uses wind tunnels to gain a vertical edge, grappling hooks to traverse impassable gaps, and attacks as a sort of double jump. She also has access to many of the Knights abilities, including the dash and wall jump. However, those four seconds of footage at the Nintendo Direct showed that Hornet has other obstacles her predecessor never had to cross.

Hollow Knight: Silksong to Introduce Sloped Environments

One of the most prevalent changes from the first game shown in the Nintendo Direct Switch 2 reveal was a sloped platform that Hornet slides down. Hornet is shown in an environment covered in what looks like either cotton balls or, more thematically, silk balls. Hornet reaches a spike-covered gap in the slope, does an acrobatic spinning flip jump over the spikes, and lands gracefully on the other side before continuing her slide downwards. It is the first time that players have seen a sloped environment like this in Hollow Knight.

This environmental change is in line with Team Cherrys vision for Hollow Knight: Silksong . On the developer's official website for the game, Team Cherry states that players will be able to Engage in lethal acrobatic action and Wield a whole new suite of nimble moves as Hornet. It seems that these nimble moves will include sliding down sloped platforms. This runs counter to the level design of the first Hollow Knight , which maintained flat platforms throughout, even in its more vertical sections.

Hollow Knight: Silksong's Premise Teased New Environments

The kingdom of Hollow Knight: Silksong is also set to be larger than the first, which would lend itself well to Hornets nimbler playstyle. That said, the official website states that the player's goal will be to ascend to the shining citadel at the top of the world. Ascend is the key word here. Rather than moving deeper into the world to reach the goal, Hornet will be climbing up. This may limit the number of sliding sections in the game, but thats not to say that the whole game will be moving in a down-to-up direction. If the first Hollow Knight is any indicator, players will likely have to go down sometimes in order to go up. Such is the nature of Metroidvania-style games.

It also begs the question of what other types of environments players should expect in Hollow Knight: Silksong . Maneuverability seems to be the key here, and previous trailers have shown environments with a lot of moving parts. How Team Cherry plans to incorporate all of these new environmental pieces to create variety in the level design waits to be seen. Whichever direction Team Cherry intends to go up, down, sideways, and now diagonally players should have faith that they are holding off on revealing too much because they want to maintain a degree of surprise when Hollow Knight: Silksong finally drops later in 2025. The four-second Nintendo Direct clip and previous trailers are just a small taste of whats to come.

item.title: New Pixel Art Life Sim Is Like a Spooky Stardew Valley
item.description:
Summary

  • Neverway, a horror life sim with RPG elements, combines horror-themed visuals with charming pixel art.
  • The new indie title was developed by Coldblood Inc., a studio co-founded by Celeste's pixel artist Pedro Medeiros.
  • It also features player-driven customization through building, crafting, and a morality system that affects character interactions adds depth to the game.

Neverway , a new life sim from indie developer Coldblood Inc., has been announced for PC. The studio was co-founded by Pedro Medeiros, the pixel artist behind Celeste and a contributor to acclaimed indie titles like TowerFall . In Neverway , players step into the role of an ordinary girl who gains immortality through a dead god. Unlike Celeste' s mostly linear progression, Neverway seems to adopt an RPG approach, featuring farming, fishing, crafting, building, and dating mechanics.

Celeste is widely regarded as one of the best precision platformer games of the decade, praised in part for its charming pixel art style. Now, Coldblood Inc.'s debut title, Neverway , seems to deliver equally delightful visuals, thanks to the same creative artist. Based on the announcement trailer, the game seems to cleverly blend horrifying imagery with an adorable aesthetic.

Announced on April 10, Neverway is now available for enthusiastic fans to wishlist on Steam for Windows, macOS, SteamOS, and Linux. While a release date hasn't been confirmed, the game has revealed its recommended PC specs, suggesting it may be nearing completion. Neverway' s gameplay appears to take cues from popular cozy games, featuring elements like a dating system similar to Stardew Valley' s, with over ten datable NPCs, as well as a series of dungeons the protagonist, Fiona, must clear to "pay her debt."

Neverway Is a Horror Life Sim with Role-Playing Elements

One of the more intriguing aspects of Neverway is its focus on player-driven customization through crafting and building. The game appears to incorporate RPG mechanics, including spells, buffs, and items that influence how players engage with the world, as each potential relationship with an NPC grants unique abilities to aid the player's journey. There also seems to be a morality system reminiscent of Lies of P , where players may choose between honesty and deception in character interactions, though the developer has not officially confirmed this feature.

For those curious, Neverway is being developed using the Murder Engine, an open-source pixel art ECS game engine created by Coldblood Inc. co-founder Isadora Sophia. Another noteworthy detail is that the game is funded by Outersloth Fund, a video game investment company backed by Innersloth, the developer and publisher of Among Us . Fans paying close attention to the announcement trailer might also spot a subtle nod to Among Us : the protagonist wears a T-shirt featuring a Crewmate. It's worth noting that Neverway was the opening title of 2025's Triple-I Initiative livestream, and more details about the game are expected to be revealed in the near future.

item.title: Interview: Once Upon A Puppet Dev Discusses Gameplay, Character Dynamics, and More
item.description:
Developer Flatter Than Earth and publisher Daedalic Entertainment are combining 2.5D platforming and the theater with Once Upon A Puppet , a new game set to launch across all major platforms on April 23. Taking place in a magical kingdom built to resemble a marionette stage show, Once Upon A Puppet puts players in the starring role of two unlikely protagonists. Nieve is a disgraced Stagehand who finds herself bound to a young Puppet by the name of Drev, and the pair must journey to discover the mystery of their predicament and save the world from a consuming darkness.

Game Rant recently spoke to one of the developers of Once Upon A Puppet to learn more about how Flatter Than Earth first came up with the idea for a side-scroller that lets players control both a puppet and the hand literally pulling its strings. They also shared insight into how this symbiotic connection is reflected in Once Upon A Puppet s gameplay, how the theater influenced the games setting and characters, and the way that in-game collectibles are tied to Once Upon A Puppet s lore. This interview has been edited for clarity.

Once Upon A Puppets Theatrical Origins Explained

Q. Where did the idea for a puppet and theater-themed platformer come from?

A. The inspiration for Once Upon a Puppet came from a moment of realization. I was already exploring the idea of a game where a character marionettes a puppet, but I wasnt sure what kind of world they belonged in. Then, I saw a photo of a theater stage. At first, I just scrolled past it, but something made me go back. That image stuck with me.

Suddenly, it clicked - puppets and theater are a perfect match. Thats their natural stage, both literally and metaphorically. From that moment on, everything made sense. I dove deep into researching both theater and puppetry, understanding how they work, their visual language, and how we could translate them into a game. Once that connection was made, there was no going back.

Q. Can you talk a little bit about Once Upon a Puppets development journey? What did day one look like, and what have the past few months looked like?

A. Once Upon a Puppet started as a small idea, just a rough concept of a game with a puppet controlled by another character. The early days were all about discovery, testing different mechanics, and understanding how puppetry could work in gameplay. A big focus was on movement - how do you make a puppet feel like a puppet, rather than just another platforming character?

As development progressed, we went through a lot of iterations. At first, not everyone on the team fully saw the vision. I spent a lot of time showing them references from theater productions, explaining why this direction was powerful. Once we aligned, the game really came to life.

The past year was about refinement, fine-tuning the controls, polishing the visuals, and making sure the storytelling was as strong as it could be. A lot of love has gone into making the world feel rich, immersive, and deeply theatrical.

Q. What were some of the biggest challenges you faced when translating these puppet/theater themes into story or gameplay?

A. One of the biggest challenges was movement. A puppet doesnt move like a regular character in a platformer. We didnt want Drev to just feel like another Mario or Hollow Knight - his movement had to reflect real puppetry. We studied how marionettes move, how the tension in strings affects motion, and how we could make that part of the gameplay.

Another challenge was selling the idea of a theatrical world. We wanted it to feel like a grand stage production, with lighting, set changes, and dramatic storytelling. That meant designing a world that flowed like a Broadway show rather than a confined stage and making sure our 2.5D cutscenes captured that theatrical magic.

Q. What would you say the overall theme of Once Upon A Puppet is?

A. Besides the theme of theater and puppetry, at its core , Once Upon a Puppet is a story about fate, redemption, and self-discovery, which is interwoven very deeply into the story of the King and his son, the Prince. Nieve is a visitor to this arc, yet Drev is part of it.

Speaking of them, Drev and Nieve are literally bound together and must learn to work as one. Their journey is deeply personal, yet intertwined with the larger world of the theater and the fate of the Prince.

Q. Can you talk a little bit about how the game takes advantage of the relationship between hand and puppet? Was gameplay natural in this regard, or did it take a lot of iteration to get right?

It definitely took a lot of iteration! The core idea - one character controlling another like a puppet, felt unique from the start, but making it feel good took time. We had to balance the feeling of control with the unpredictability of a puppets movement.

For example, Nieve doesnt just control Drev directly, theres a dynamic between them. Drev has his own personality, his own ambitions, and sometimes his movements reflect that. We wanted to make sure players felt like they were truly puppeteering BOTH characters, not just pressing a button to move.

Q. Similarly, can you talk a little bit about fitting puppet gameplay into platformer mechanics, like Drev being able to catapult himself?

A. This was another area where we had to rethink traditional platforming. A puppet doesnt have the same kind of direct control over its movement, so we had to be creative.

Drevs ability to catapult himself comes from the idea of manipulating puppet strings. Instead of just pressing jump, the player has to work with the physics of puppetry, pulling back, releasing, and using momentum to their advantage. It creates a different kind of challenge, one that feels more in line with the puppeteering-like theme.

Q. What would you say the overall puzzle ethos is in Once Upon a Puppet?

A. The puzzles in Once Upon a Puppet are built around theatrical storytelling and stage mechanics. Players dont just solve puzzles in isolation, theyre actively setting up a stage, arranging props, and performing actions that feel like part of a play.

The key idea is transformation: how do you change the stage to advance? That could mean moving backdrops, adjusting lighting, or even stepping into different roles through costumes. The puzzles are meant to feel like theyre part of a grand performance, where every action contributes to the unfolding story.

Also, beware hardcore puzzle players. Once Upon A Puppet is more of a casual puzzler. At FTE, we believe that puzzle platformers are fragile; you get stuck once, and you turn off the game. I did not want that for OUaP , I want the player to keep playing and not get stuck on one puzzle. The whole experience, from A to Z, is what we tried to help the player with.

Q. Promotional materials mention a colorful cast of supporting characters. How did you approach designing these characters?

A. A big inspiration was actual stage productions, how actors take on exaggerated personas, and how costumes and set design tell a story. We wanted every character to feel like they belonged in this world, from their design to their dialogue.

Each character has a theatrical flair. Some are dramatic, some are comedic, but all of them contribute to the feeling that youre in a living, breathing theater production. And just like in a real play, every character plays a role in the larger story.

Overall, we put a lot of effort into our characters and their details. We really wanted to create a standout case.

Q. The Steam demo includes some collectible glass window shards to collect. What do the collectibles add to Once Upon a Puppets gameplay?

A. Collectibles in Once Upon a Puppet serve a deeper purpose than just completionism. The Stained Glass pieces, for example, are tied to the games story, and each one reveals part of a larger mystery. Collecting them isnt just about unlocking rewards; its about piecing together the hidden history of our theater world.

They also help in exploring the world, allow the player to be perceptive, look into the theater and notice the stained glass shards.

Beyond that, we have ideas that we would love to implement for the sequel. So keep playing and recommending OUaP to your friends. The future of the sequel depends on it.

Q. What are Flatter Than Earths plans come Once Upon A Puppet launches in April? Can you share any ideas for your next project?

A. Right now, were fully focused on making sure Once Upon a Puppet launches in the best possible state. We want players to experience the full theatrical magic weve worked so hard to create.

As for whats next, we always have ideas brewing. Our studio is built on the idea of crafting unique, imaginative worlds, so you can expect something just as creative as Once Upon a Puppet . But for now, were letting this game take center stage.

Q. Is there anything else you would like to add?

A. I just want to say thank you to everyone who has supported Once Upon a Puppet . This game has been a labor of love, and we cant wait for players to experience it. Whether youre a fan of platformers, theater, or just great storytelling, we hope youll find something special in this world weve created. And remember, every stage tells a story. Its up to you to bring it to life.

Also - if youre interested in more indie titles like this one, theres a wealth of games out there in the retro space that are also doing some really cool stuff - like 8-Bit Adventures 2 , Chained Echoe s, and Quartet !

[END]

item.title: Nintendo Switch Online Adds 3 Classic Sega Genesis Games
item.description:
Summary

  • Nintendo Switch Online adds Sega Genesis games, including Streets of Rage, for Expansion Pack subscribers.
  • Launch of Nintendo Switch 2 on June 5 will bring GameCube titles to Switch Online + Expansion Pack.

Nintendo Switch Online has added three classic Sega Genesis games Streets of Rage, Super Thunder Blade, and ESWAT: City Under Siege to the library of titles available with the Expansion Pack. Fans of retro video games can get access to NES, SNES, and Game Boy favorites with a regular Switch Online subscription, and the Expansion Pack adds many iconic N64, Game Boy Advance, and Sega Genesis games to the selection.

Once the Nintendo Switch 2 launches on June 5, Switch Online + Expansion Pack subscribers will be able to enjoy Game Cube titles as well. The announcement that the beloved console would be coming to the service was one of the highlights of the April 2 Nintendo Direct Showcase, and the first games on offer will be F-Zero GX, The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, and Soulcalibur 2.

In the meantime, gamers will be enjoying regular additions to the catalog and other perks like free upgrades via their Switch Online subscription. On April 10, Streets of Rage, Super Thunder Blade, and ESWAT: City Under Siege became available for Expansion Pack subscribers to check out. These classic Sega Genesis titles offer something for fans of side scrollers, flight sims, and beat em ups.

Games Added to Switch Online + Expansion Pack in April

  • ESWAT: City Under Siege
  • Streets of Rage
  • Super Thunder Blade

Of the three new games, Streets of Rage might be the most recognizable, as its 1991 release marked the beginning of a long-lived and successful franchise that comprises four games, numerous fan projects, comics, and short stories. As recently as 2022, there was even a Streets of Rage feature film and television series in the works by Lionsgate, though there havent been any updates on that project in a while. This Switch Online addition is a side-scrolling beat em up that pits former police officers against a crime syndicate that has set up base in the fictional city of Wood Oak.

Another side scroller, this time a platformer, ESWAT: City Under Siege was released in 1990. A port of a popular arcade game of the time, with some new levels and weapons tossed into the mix, ESWAT also puts players in the boots of a police officer on a mission to clean up the streets. But despite the similarities in presentation and setting, this Switch Online newcomer offers a completely different experience to Streets of Rage.

The combat flight simulator Super Thunder Blade also pits players against relentless bad guys, but shakes things up a bit by giving them a helicopter to use as a weapon instead. Released in 1988, the popular game has been ported a few times, to PS2 and PSP in 2007 and Xbox 360 and PS3 in 2009, and fans are excited to see it join the many games available with a Switch Online + Expansion Pack subscription.
